data.title: Option to show generated GLSL code
fixed math in Camera::project_position
data.body:
The mouse coordinates are now properly mapped from 2D to 3D. Old bugged version mapped 
top left corner of window (0,0) to bottom left corner of camera viewport (eg. to negative y-axis instead of positive y-axis).

data.title: yield() crashes with two local variales
data.body:
There seems something fishy with `yield()` and local variables. I have the simplest scene, with a button and AnimationPlayer. Animation starts when then button is pressed:

```
func _on_Button_pressed():
    var anim = get_node("AnimationPlayer")
    #var foo = 1

    anim.play("slide")
    print("started")
    yield(Object(anim), "finished")
    print("finished")
```

This works as expected, godot prints "started", plays the animation and then prints "finished". Now, when I uncomment `var foo = 1`, it crashes with sigsegv (sorry, no stack trace... all I see is "started" and no "finished").

To me it seems `yield()` does not like more than one local variable. But keeping local variables is the foundantion block of coroutines!

Tested on godot 1.0, win64.

data.title: Cant pass anything to CanvasItemShader
data.body: Since setting shader's paramiters is only a available in MaterialShader, which can't be attached to CanvasItems, there is no way to pass any variables to shader in 2D - like uniforms. I tried to make a material and then use get_shader(), but returned shader hasn't got any binded values after doing it. I know that it can be done from the inspector, but I need that functionality incode.

data.title: Sprites turn black after exiting the game and going back in on Android with Adreno 200 GPU
data.body:
Every time I press the home button to exit the game, and when I later return to it, the sprites are all black.

These images show [before](http://i.imgur.com/VYUohgG.jpg) and [after](http://i.imgur.com/LxyZ7pq.jpg).

data.title: Exporting to android makes Godot UI hang
data.body:
When exporting to an android device the UI completely freezes. To the point that whenever I switch workspaces it sometimes even won't redraw. (I'm on linux)

I would guess that's because the export happens on some main drawing thread where it probably belongs in a separate thread.

data.title: Multiline comments support is broken in GDScript
data.body:
When I put multiline comments like this:

```
'''
 Multiline comment
 Multiline comment
 Multiline comment
'''
```

...or this:

```
"""
 Multiline comment
 Multiline comment
 Multiline comment
"""
```

Godot complains saying:

```
error(line, column): Unexpected token: Constant:
Parser error: Unexpected token: Constant:
```

where `line,column` is the first line and first character where the  triple-quoted string starts

**_Update**_

It seems to work when the triple-quote is preceded by a space or a tab character

```
 """<--preceded by a space
this works ok
"""
    """<--preceded by a tab character
this works too
"""
```

data.title: Godot`s source code namaing convention is just wrong!
data.body: Hello,everyone who use Godot know that this is a good pice of software and well made.But since this project is open source many people like me for example would like to know how godot works.So we look into the source code and explore but there is one BIG problem.In Neo engine for example or Maratis the hole engine is well documenteated inside it`s source code.And the names of the variables are easy to understand what they do and why.So since every developer who makes it`s project open source wants to build a community around the project many people would want to add new features to that project.But in this case this can`t be achive since it`s extremly hard to get your head around the spaghetti :).So in the end this is an open source game engine or a "wolf cosumed in a sheep"?

data.title: Replace shader language with GLSL
data.body:
(split this off from #1315)

Since godot is using GLSL only for shaders, what is the point of having an in-house shader language? It's not that I mind learning a new language (like GDScript, for example), the problem is, it's a hugely crippled subset of GLSL that doesn't even have arrays or structs and simply put a HUGE pain to work with.

_It's nothing more than a toy language, lacking features preventing to write real-world programs that try go beyond simple shaders. Period._

I wish you saved us trouble of this toy "shader language" and just let use write in GLSL --you know, like real programmers do. Just wishing :)

I mean, given that it compiles into and only into GLSL and "shader language" is just a hugely crippled subset of GLSL except for the mul -> \* syntactic sugar, why not? Is it even necessary?

Pre-defined variables/structs like in Unity should work just fine to pass certain things between engine and shader. In fact, it's already what you're doing with things like "SRC_VERTEX" or "DIFFUSE", except that they're not in a struct.

Please consider this seriously.
Unless this is changed in the future, for anyone using shaders seriously (practically any non-indie game), I can't see much of a future in godot.

data.title: Mesh animation distortion when importing Collada (from blender export)
data.body:
### Issue

After importing an animated mesh, and accessing the animation player, the mesh is fine for the first frame on any animation strip. When moving to another frame (or playing) then moving back to the first frame, the mesh is suddenly distorted and cannot be restored until the scene is reloaded.
### Steps to reproduce:
- In Blender, pose the armature in a transformed state (move it around etc).
- Export it using the "Better collada exporter"
- Import in Godot using Import->"3D Scene"
- Open the scene's Animation player in Godot.
- Push play or just move to another frame.
  - Notice the distortion
- Move back to frame 0 and it still remains etc.
- You can now repopen the scene and the distortion will be gone.

This is after first importing the mesh.

![showing_ok_mesh_first_frame](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8754559/5971677/361dd2c0-a808-11e4-9e14-088b0e34d0a6.png)

After moving away from frame 0 in the animation player (by playing etc). Moving back to frame zero retains distortion, as seen here:

![messed_up_first_frame](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8754559/5971661/d36dc874-a807-11e4-92c7-bebe08b2d4b3.png)

If you reopen the scene it will look normal again, until you animate.  The same behavior is seen if you animate in code, by referencing any animation name (even if they just contain the rest pose).
### Workaround

The issue appears to be when exporting if you leave the armature in a transformed state (not in the rest identity transform, pose).  As seen here:

![default_pose_blender](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8754559/5971694/79758b44-a808-11e4-81cb-e1174d008b20.png)

The solution is to clear all rotations, scale and translations in pose mode before exporting.  Additionally I made a "default" animation strip as the first animation and have 1 frame with just the rest pose.

Shown here:

![rest_pose](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/8754559/5971714/ea9254b0-a808-11e4-84d5-d20c6ff899da.png)

The project is here: 
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0By6FH_3O43IRWnBtWWhUYXhuQVU/view?usp=sharing
- The blender file located under RawAssets->3d_santa.blend
- The Collada file is under RawAssets->3d_santa.dae

data.title: Allow arrays in shaders
data.body:
Not sure if this even needs a justification, but here is why I just needed them.
There is a huge class of shaders that use lookup tables, in the form of arrays.

Ordered dithering, color quantization, noise, many others to count...
Seriously, no arrays? :D

And it shouldn't be difficult to implement, right? (other than the fact that godot seems to have a hand-written lexer) After all, you don't really need to implement any language feature, godot just transpiles it to GLSL.

data.title: Absolute path in .res file
data.body:
I would like to confirm is Godot store absolute path in .res file, I found that because my main PC's Document folder is store in drive E: (because OS is store in SSD C:, others like Documents, Pictures, Music, Videos are store in E:)

My Godot project folder is store in E:, after copy the project to another PC, which has only 1 hard drive C:, Godot cannot load the image because it cannot find image in E:\ drive.

When I open the .res file, although it is not a plain text file, I found the absolute path "E:/Users/flim/Documents/" inside.

data.body:
I got this message when editing and saving a script "GDScript(43817)" inside a instance scene.
Sometime the editor can save the script sometimes not.

I don't have this problem with script as file *.gd.

```
ERROR: save_ressource: Condition ' p_resource.is_null() || p_resource->get_path()=="" || p_resource->get_path().find("::")!=-1 ' is true.
At: tools/editor/editor_node.cpp 389
```

data.title: "Triangulate" option of Better Collada Exporter not compatible with "Shape-Keys" (morph) animations.
data.body:
Hi,

With recent custom build.

The "Triangulate" option of the Better Collada Exporter is not really compatible with "Shape-Keys" (morph) animations.

If the "shape-key" animated mesh contains polygons other than triangles, and if it is exported with "triangulate" option set to ON, then, once imported into Godot, the vertices of each morph targets won't match. (I tried with a simple deformed cube)

If you re-export it with "triangulate" to OFF, then, Godot will warn you about "Primitive polygon not well supported (concave shape may fail)".

The only workaround i've found is to triangulate the mesh using a modifier into Blender, just before creating the Shape-keys.

data.title: [Documentation] Vector2's slide() and reflect() methods have wrong return value
data.body:
In documentation the next methods have float as return value:

float Vector2::reflect( Vector2 vec )
float Vector2::slide( Vector2 vec )

but i'm very sure their return value is a Vector2:

Steps to reproduce:

func _ready
    var v = Vector2(-3,1)
    v = v.slide(Vector2(2,4))
    print(v)

as a result, the text <-4,6> will be printed, wich is of course a Vector2

data.title: Dictionary has random ordering
data.body:
Hi,

I'm using a recent windows custom build.

I don't know if it is a bug or a missing feature, but parsing a Dictionnary returns keys in random order.

```
func _ready():

    var dico = {
        A = "1 - April",
        B = "2 - Banana",
        C = "3 - Cocoa",
        D = "4 - Drum",
        E = "5 - Elephant",
    }

    for k in dico :
        print(k," : ",dico[k])
```

returns keys in this order :

```
C : 3 - Cocoa
D : 4 - Drum
E : 5 - Elephant
A : 1 - April
B : 2 - Banana
```

I fail to see the coherence of this behavior.
It could be far more usefull if the ordering was the same the keys were entered into the dictionnary, ~~or at least ordered alphabetically~~.

data.title: Get node by type method
data.body: Is it possible to find a node / child by class rather than name?

data.title: PolygonPathFinder
data.body:
_SOME NEW FEATURES REQUEST_

Current PolygonPathFinder is poor. It could use some more functions like:
- creating straight from Polygon2D
- creating from TileMap
- creating from objects array (using their shapes or sprites f.e.)
- using shapes to calculate routes
- path offset

At the moment it is only useful when creating route through static, pre-defined environment; while assuming that object moving through this path is of point size (or smaller), unless the path was offseted manually.

Creating any dynamic pathfind usually ends up with strange routes because of badly interpreted connections ( there can't be more than 1 line going through 1 point? ) or overlapping polygons.

I'd say current [polygon_path_finder_demo](https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/tree/master/demos/2d/polygon_path_finder_demo) is the best example of current PolygonPathFinder capabilities :(

data.title: Adjustment to x11/detect.py
data.body:
Test if clang is defined in CC/CXX/LD - this allows a specific version of clang to be defined, which may be a full path or have a version suffix.
Move appending -DTYPED_METHOD_BIND to keep clang options together

Move sanitize option out of use_llvm test, gcc48+ also supports sanitize=address
Not sure with env.extra_suffix after sanitize, would this way leave a trailing 's' not in a location desired?

data.title: fix build on freebsd
data.body:
I have got godot to build and run on FreeBSD. I needed to make the following source changes, they are all #if'd so shouldn't interfere with anything else.

Add some needed includes
Provide freebsd variation of get_executable_path
Provide variation of execv so that either full path or appname to be found within $PATH can be used

data.title: Additional UI color options
data.body: While obviously not the most pressing issue, it would make sense to add more color options in the Godot UI, or defaulting to a dark gray. I find the purple UI too distracting since it's not a neutral color.

data.title: Better collada: UnboundLocalError: local variable 'img_tmp_path'
data.body:
Hi,

I think I have found a bug with the collada exporter. I get the following traceback:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/__init__.py", line 179, in execute
    return export_dae.save(self, context, **keywords)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 1646, in save
    exp.export()
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 1571, in export
    self.export_scene()
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 1269, in export_scene
    self.export_node(obj,2)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 1223, in export_node
    self.export_node(x,il)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 1212, in export_node
    self.export_mesh_node(node,il)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 907, in export_mesh_node
    meshdata = self.export_mesh(node,armature)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 544, in export_mesh
    materials[f.material_index]=self.export_material( mat,mesh.show_double_sided )
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 256, in export_material
    imgid = self.export_image(ts.texture.image)
  File "/home/xxx/.config/blender/2.73/scripts/addons/io_scene_dae/export_dae.py", line 215, in export_image
    if img_tmp_path.endswith((".bmp",".rgb",".png",".jpeg",".jpg",".jp2",".tga",".cin",".dpx",".exr",".hdr",".tif")):
UnboundLocalError: local variable 'img_tmp_path' referenced before assignment
```

As far as I can see, this variable never gets defined. And putting in img_tmp_path = image.filepath results in no error, but some images seem to be missing :)

Cheers!
Benedikt

data.title: Typo in Wiki
data.body:
https://github.com/okamstudio/godot/wiki/compiling_intro

Very last sentence on the page "...setup this", should be "set this up".

data.title: Fix init crash on iPad 1st gen device with iOS 5.1.1
data.body:
I was experiencing a crash on my old device when running with the stable version of the engine.
It seemed that the glview was not updated before the didBecomeActive was called in app_delegate.mm, which caused the OS::singleton field to not be set properly raising an EXC_BAD_ACCESS in didBecomeActive call.

data.title: Fix iOS Simulator SDK path for isim platform.
data.body: The python script worked only if 7.1 SDK was installed. In case of a Xcode fresh install, only 8.1 SDK is available, so the 7.1 SDK is not available. This should fix the path for every SDK.

data.title: scons: *** [drivers\libdrivers1.windows.tools.32.a] Wrong parameters
data.body:
Hello,

I tried to compile Godot Engine under Windows 8 with Python 2.7.9, openssl 1.0.1L and Scons 2.3.4 with the command `scons platform=windows`.

This is the error message I get when it aborts the compilation:
`scons: *** [drivers\libdrivers1.windows.tools.32.a] Wrong parameters
scons: building terminated because of errors.`

Is it a bug or is it my fault?

data.title: == operator not working on references to arrays/dictionary with recursive references
data.body:
Made a demo to show this:
https://github.com/ScyDev/godot/tree/master/demos/crashes/recursive_reference_compare_fail

Godot should handle recursive references better. Cut them off when necessary, during print() or a comparision.

PHP does this well.
